title-group.article-title: Morphology, Surgical Techniques, and Outcomes in Patients Above 15 Years Undergoing Surgery for Congenitally Corrected Transposition of Great Arteries

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: There is a paucity of data about morphology, surgical procedure, and results in older patients with congenitally corrected transposition of great arteries (ccTGAs).

sec.title: Patients and Methods:
sec.p: Between January 2002 and August 2012, 15 patients (7 males), median age 25 years, range 16 to 41 years underwent surgery for ccTGA. Associated lesions were tricuspid regurgitation (TR; n = 5) and ventricular septal defect (VSD) with pulmonary stenosis (PS; n = 10). Surgical procedures included tricuspid valve replacement (n = 4), tricuspid valve repair (n = 1), lateral tunnel Fontan (n = 2), extracardiac Fontan (n = 2), Kawashima procedure (n = 1), bidirectional (BD) Glenn (n = 2), Senning + Rastelli procedure (n = 1), and VSD closure + left ventricle to pulmonary artery conduit (n = 1). The details of these procedures and outcomes were analyzed.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: There were no early or late deaths. Mean follow-up period was 49.9 ± 26 months. All patients who underwent tricuspid valve replacement are in New York Heart Association (NYHA) class I, with no progression of right ventricular (RV) dysfunction. One patient who underwent tricuspid valve repair is in NYHA class III and has progressed to severe RV dysfunction. None of the patients undergoing single ventricle palliation had any complications related to the surgery. Both patients who underwent anatomical and physiological biventricular (BV) repair had no complications.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Older patients with ccTGA present a challenge. Fontan/BD Glenn remains a good option for patients who presented with VSD PS. Both anatomic and physiological BV repairs provide acceptable results. Tricuspid valve replacement is safe for patients presenting with TR who have improvement in functional class, though the right ventricular function may not improve.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Congenitally corrected transposition of great arteries (ccTGA), or atrioventricular and ventriculoarterial discordance, is an uncommon defect, accounting for 1% of all congenital heart disease (CHD). 1 This CHD may be first diagnosed in adulthood or even in an elderly patient.

Such patients may present with symptoms related to systemic right ventricular dysfunction, 2 cardiac conduction defects, and arrhythmias. There are also reports in the literature of the diagnosis of isolated ccTGA being made in previously asymptomatic adult patient during investigation of coronary events, even in the sixth or seventh decades of life. The conventional management strategy for these patients has been physiological surgical repair that includes isolated ventricular septal defect (VSD) repair with or without insertion of an left ventricle (LV) to pulmonary artery (PA) conduit and repair or replacement of the regurgitant systemic atrioventricular (AV) valve. 3,4,5

More recent surgical approaches have focused on the “anatomic” repairs that return the LV to the systemic circulation and may therefore result in improved long-term prognosis. Patients without LV outflow obstruction in whom the pulmonary valve is suitable to function as a neoaortic valve may be approached using the double-switch procedure, which combines (1) the Senning atrial baffle procedure, which redirects blood flow at the atrial level, with (2) the arterial switch procedure where the great arteries are transected and reversed. Successful outcome after this procedure is dependent on the LV being adequately prepared for functioning at systemic arterial pressure. For patients with obstruction to LV outflow tract, the Senning atrial baffle and an RV to PA conduit using the Rastelli principle is a suitable option. In some patients, the aortic root translocation (Nikaidoh operation) along with a Senning operation may be tried to achieve an anatomic biventricular (BV) repair. Finally for those patients with ccTGA, VSD and pulmonary stenosis (PS) with difficulty in routing the VSD to the aorta or other contraindications to anatomical repair, univentricular repair is an acceptable palliation. 3,6,7

There is limited data on the management of patients presenting late in childhood and in adulthood, 8 as most of the patients are operated in early childhood in developed countries. In this report, we present our experience with this condition over the last 10 years.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Between January 2002 and August 2012, 15 patients with ccTGA aged above 15 years underwent surgery in the department of cardiothoracic and vascular surgery at All India Institute of Medical Sciences, New Delhi, India. The detailed records of these patients were studied. Retrospective data collection was performed after ethical clearance by the institute ethics committee. Patients’ preoperative characteristics, chest x-ray findings, echocardiographic findings, cardiac catheterization data, details of surgical procedures, intraoperative details, postoperative course, and follow-up details as noted in the case records were analyzed. The data collection was performed form the cardiac clinic files and hospital record files of the patients.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed using SPSS version 15.0 (SPSS Inc, Chicago, Illinois). Nominal variables are presented as frequency and percentage, nonparametric data as median (range), and parametric data as mean and standard deviation.

sec.title: Clinical Presentation
sec.p: Of the 15 patients, 7 were male. The mean age was 23.7 ± 8 years (median 25 years, range 16-41 years). Five (33%) among the late presenters had no abnormality other than severe AV valve regurgitation and were of median age 29 years (range 23-35 years). The remaining patients (n = 10) had presented with cyanosis and had associated VSD PS in age group ranging from 16 to 41 years, the mean saturation of these patients in room air was 82% ± 6%. Three among these patients had history of hemoptysis.

Conduction abnormalities were present in four (26%) patients with two patients (13%) presenting with complete heart block (CHB) and two patients (13%) with atrial fibrillation (AF) preoperatively. The details of the presentation, demographics, and surgeries performed are presented in Table 1. The mean follow-up period was 49 ± 26 months.

sec.p: The criteria for choosing a particular surgical procedure and outcomes in each subset are as described below (Figure 1).

caption.p: Surgical options in adult patients with congenitally corrected transposition.

sec.title: Systemic AV Valve (Tricuspid Valve) Replacement/Repair (n = 5)
sec.p: Of the 15 patients, 5 (33%) presented with dyspnea on exertion and with echocardiographic diagnosis of severe systemic AV valve regurgitation with moderate systemic ventricular dysfunction and echocardiographically determined ejection fraction (EF) of about 50% (range 45%-55%). There was annular dilation along with leaflet thickening and prolapse of one or more cusps in all patients. Only one patient had an Ebsteinoid tricuspid valve. No other anomaly was detected. Of these, four underwent valve replacement and one patient underwent valve repair. All the valve replacements were accompanied with total chordal preservation and a bioprosthetic valve was implanted.

One patient underwent systemic AV valve repair (commisuroplasty + chordal shortening) as there was elongation of the chordae and anterior leaflet prolapse of the tricuspid valve. All these patients had no other associated anomaly. One of these patients (n = 1 of 5, 20%) had preoperative CHB and had transvenous permanent pacemaker implantation (PPI). Another patient had preoperative AF. Postoperative CHB occurred in one patient. All these patients had a normal postoperative course and were discharged uneventfully.

Follow-up echo findings of this group ranged from 24 to 96 months. Four patients who have undergone AV valve replacement had moderate systemic ventricular dysfunction with EF of around 45% (no improvement/deterioration) with improvement in symptoms to New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class II and no new occurrence of CHB. One patient who had undergone AV repair had only mild central regurgitation at the time of discharge from the hospital. However, the regurgitation increased progressively to become severe by the end of second year of follow-up. This was accompanied by a progressive worsening of symptoms to NYHA class III dyspnea and echocardiographic findings of severe systemic AV valve regurgitation and severe systemic ventricular dysfunction with EF 30% at the end of 72 months. This patient is awaiting reoperation presently.

sec.title: Bidirectional Glenn, Total Cavopulmonary Connection (Univentricular Palliation; n = 8)
sec.p: Bidirectional (BD) Glenn anastomosis was performed for the following indications: hypoplastic right ventricle + large VSD and PS (n = 1), nonroutable VSD to aorta with normal BV function, PS, and dextrocardia (n = 1), normal BV function + VSD, PS, situs ambiguous + interrupted inferior vena cava (IVC; n = 1). Three patients underwent BD Glenn procedures. Among them, one patient had interrupted IVC who had left superior vena cava and underwent bilateral BD Glenn, that is Kawashima operation (equivalent to total cavopulmonary connection [TCPC]), the other patient who had undergone prior PA banding and a BT shunt had small left PA and anatomy unsuitable for TCPC, the last among these children had anatomy unsuitable for placement of conduit from IVC to PA. All of them had antegrade pulmonary blood flow left open after the Glenn procedure.

Total cavopulmonary connection was performed in four (n = 4 of 8) of these patients having normal PA pressures, two had lateral tunnel Fontan procedure with fenestration and the other two had extracardiac Fontan procedure, among these patients three had single ventricle physiology in which one had multiple muscular VSDs and one patient had normal BV function with large VSD that was not routable to aorta. One patient (other than the eight patients in the single-ventricle group) who had undergone BD Glenn earlier was taken up for Fontan completion, but the procedure was abandoned as there were dense adhesions and anatomy was not identified for placement of a graft (intra-/extracardiac). One patient who underwent intracardiac TCPC had undergone Holter examination, which revealed sinus tachycardia with right bundle branch block pattern. The mean duration of intensive care unit (ICU) stay was 4.5 days (range 2-8 days). The mean chest tube drainage period was seven days (range four-nine days). None of these patients had any prolonged chest tube drainage (>10 days) nor prolonged stay in ICU. Postoperative saturation was above 95% in all the patients except one in whom Fontan completion was abandoned.

sec.title: Follow-Up
sec.p: All these patients are under regular follow-up (18-60 months). None of these patients have worsening cyanosis or have undergone reintervention or new occurrence of arrhythmias. One patient who had undergone Kawashima procedure, and PPI implantation due to preoperative CHB recently had an uneventful pregnancy.

sec.title: Rastelli + Senning Procedure (n = 1)
sec.p: This procedure was performed in one patient (age 18 years) with ccTGA VSD PS with normal BV function and normal branch PAs in which the VSD was routable to the aorta. There was mild right AV valve regurgitation detected on echocardiography. A standard atrial switch procedure was performed followed by VSD closure through the RV and a 24 Biocor valved RV to PA conduit (Biocor Industriae Pesquisa Ltda, Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil) was placed. This patient had an uneventful postoperative course and had normal sinus rhythm with normal BV function postoperatively. At 60 months of follow-up, he had normal BV function with no evidence of baffle/conduit obstruction and no AV valve regurgitation.

sec.title: Trans-Right Atrial VSD Closure + LV to PA Conduit (Physiological Correction)
sec.p: This procedure was performed in a 41-year-old female patient who was symptomatic with dyspnea NYHA class III and cyanosis with recurrent episodes of hemoptysis. There was dextrocardia with normal BV function and no evidence of AV valve regurgitation, with normal PA pressures on cardiac catheterization data. Physiological repair was preferred in this patient as intraoperative assessment of VSD revealed that it was not routable to the aorta, thus ruling out the option of an anatomic repair. Aortic root translocation (Nikaidoh operation) along with an atrial switch was considered to achieve an anatomical repair but was not pursued because of the technical complexity and the possibility of a long ischemia and bypass time. Physiologic repair in this patient was presumed to be a better option than TCPC at this age as this still provided a BV circulation and avoided a univentricular repair with its short-term and long-term problems. The VSD was closed through the right atrium and an LV to PA conduit (22 bovine internal jugular vein conduit) was placed. This patient had an uneventful recovery except for multiple ventricular ectopics but no evidence of heart block. Following discharge from the hospital patient is NYHA class I with stable cardiac rhythm and no cyanosis at one month of follow-up.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Congenitally corrected TGA is an unusual cardiac defect comprising less than 1% of all forms of CHD. The presence and severity of associated anomalies (presence or absence of VSD/PS) contribute to the complex and varied presentation and clinical course. Patients may present due to isolated tricuspid regurgitation (TR) and or RV dysfunction. The other modes of presentation could be due to CHB and arrhythmias. Late presentation in presence of cyanosis is particularly common in developing countries due to delay in diagnosis and or referral. These patients usually have VSD and associated PS. Only about 10% of these patients have no other anatomic abnormalities. In our study group of patients above 15 years of age, 5 (33%) patients presented with TR and RV dysfunction. The remaining 10 (77%) patients presented with cyanosis and had associated VSD and PS, out of which 2 children were seen in their childhood (8 patients presented primarily late). Two (13.3%) of them had CHB preoperatively. It has been reported that approximately 10% of children with ccTGA have CHB at initial presentation, and up to a third of patients have some degree of AV conduction delay and occurrence of spontaneous CHB has been estimated to be approximately 2% per year. The reason behind the spontaneous occurrence of CHB is because of the functional AV node being displaced anteriorly 8 and the penetrating bundle and conduction fibers that are elongated are prone to mechanical trauma over time which eventually leads to conduction block. 9 –11

Surgical approaches for management of patients with ccTGAs include physiologic versus anatomic BV repair and functionally univentricular palliation. Anatomical correction includes atrial switch + arterial switch operation or atrial switch + Rastelli operation in patients with abnormal pulmonary valve. In our series, anatomical correction (Senning +Rastelli) was performed in one patient whose anatomy was suitable for the same. This patient had an uneventful postoperative course and has no postoperative complication till date. Various studies have revealed that the Rastelli repair had the lowest mortality and morbidity rates with incidence of 8% postoperative heart block, versus 19% Amplatzer septal occluder, and 65% of physiological repair. There has also been a low incidence of 6% postoperative systemic AV valve regurgitation versus 53% physiologic repair. Encouraging intermediate term follow-up of surgical treatment of ccTGA subsets wherein the morphologic LV becomes the systemic ventricle promoted this to be a valuable option in patients in whom the anatomy is favorable in the hands of experienced surgeons. However, there have been reports of decreased long-term survival of patients undergoing the anatomical repairs 67% versus 91% for TCPC operations and this has generated a controversy. 10
–18 In a recent publication, Sharma et al showed a definite incidence of late occurrence of significant LV dysfunction in children undergoing anatomical correction for ccTGA without PS. However, in the same study, patients with ccTGA, VSD, and PS, undergoing Senning and Rastelli, seemed to have a better long-term survival despite a definitive incidence of baffle obstruction and reoperation for conduit obstruction. 19

The Fontan operation continues to be a simple alternative in patients with protected pulmonary vasculature who are unsuitable for anatomic repair. In our series, there were seven (46%) patients who underwent cavopulmonary connection (Glenn: 2, Fontan: 4, and Kawashima: 1). None of these patients were suitable for anatomical repair. The recent era has witnessed a decreased risk of Fontan operation, with a low immediate mortality. The long-term mortality and morbidity also have been very low with actuarial survival at 10 years, reaching 91% and freedom from reoperations and arrhythmias being 87%. 17
–20 The Fontan procedure has been shown to have a better late survival over the physiological repair. 21,22 When compared to the classic anatomic repairs that surgeons have been increasingly indulging in, there have been reports that suggests no advantage with anatomical repair when compared to Fontan operation (in terms of freedom from reoperation and late survival), other than in the presence of preoperative tricuspid insufficiency. 21 –23 New reports from Yasuda have demonstrated from exercise testing that there were no significant differences between patients undergoing TCPC and those undergoing anatomical repair. 24 Though we applied this procedure in the majority of patients, these patients were not candidates for anatomical repair. We believe that the Fontan operation may be the choice of operation over anatomical correction in adult patients. Selection of the procedure when faced with in such a situation will remain an important step and should be tailored to the situation. The option selected will remain a challenge in these patients presenting late in their life.

Isolated TR and right ventricular dysfunction are reported in up to 20% to 30% of patients with ccTGA. Surgical retraining the LV followed by relocation of the LV into the systemic position is an option in children and not in adults due to unfavorable outcomes. 25 –27 Isolated TR is known to appear late in adulthood in patients with ccTGA with no other anomalies. 28 We believe that it is important to address the TR once it is significant even if there is no RV dysfunction because once the RV dysfunction sets in, a combination of severe TR and RV dysfunction may lead to a poor outcome and decreased survival. 25,29 The survival at 5 years has been reported to be 78% and 65% at 10 years in patients undergoing TVR with or without concomitant prior procedures and with a 1-year survival of up to 100%. All our patients who underwent tricuspid valve procedures are in regular follow-up, with no late mortality, that is survival of 100% up to a maximum of 96 months. Results of TVR have been reported to be better than repair and annuloplasty, with recurrence of TR in up to 37% at one year in the latter category. Similarly, in one of our patients who underwent tricuspid valve repair with initial improvement, there was recurrence of TR at the end of one year. This limited observation is consistent with other studies that have suggested that TVR may be preferred over repair. 28

sec.title: Pulmonary Artery Banding as a Definitive Palliation in Adults With ccTGA
sec.p: It is quite clear that patients with ccTGA and moderate obstruction to the pulmonary outflow have a better long-term prognosis than those without such obstruction. If this is true, the placement of a pulmonary artery banding (PAB) in patients without pulmonary outflow tract obstruction would only seem to be a logical alternative. It has been shown that PAB is an effective palliation in patients in whom the morphological RV is the systemic ventricle. It has been shown to train the LV, to improve the RV function, to reduce the TR, and prevent and delay the need for cardiac transplantation. In a recent study, 30 these effects were studied in detail in 14 patients aged 0.9 to 14.9 years where PAB was used as an “open-end” palliation for systemic right ventricles. Whether this strategy will hold true for adults remains to be seen.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Patients with ccTGA presenting late in childhood and adulthood present a challenge. Fontan/BD Glenn remains a good option for patients who presented with VSD PS. Both anatomic and physiological repairs provide acceptable results, but a larger number of patients need to be studied to give guidelines.
Tricuspid valve replacement is a safe option for patients with ccTGA who present during adulthood with isolated TR.
